choices.text: Time interval between S2 and the opening snap

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with mitral stenosis is being evaluated. Which clinical finding best indicates the severity of the condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Time interval between S2 and the opening snap

 

Explanation:

 

The S2-OS (second heart sound to opening snap) interval is the best indicator of mitral stenosis severity:

 

  • Mild MS: S2-OS interval is longer (~100 ms or more)
  • Severe MS: S2-OS interval is short (~60 ms or less), indicating higher left atrial pressure

 

The earlier the opening snap occurs, the more severe the stenosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Muffled heart sounds: Seen in pericardial effusion, cardiac tamponade, not mitral stenosis

 

Option B. Loud S1: Common in MS, but may become soft in severe cases due to valve calcification

 

Option C. S3 gallop: Associated with heart failure, mitral regurgitation, not mitral stenosis

 

Educational Objective:

 

The S2-OS interval is the best clinical indicator of mitral stenosis severity, as a shorter interval reflects higher left atrial pressure and more severe disease progression.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient reports a gradual increase in breathlessness over the past few months. On physical examination, a prominent left parasternal heave is noted, along with hepatomegaly. Auscultation reveals a loud systolic murmur. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pulmonary arterial hypertension

 

Explanation:

 

The key findings strongly suggest pulmonary hypertension (PAH):

 

  • Gradual onset of dyspnea
  • Left parasternal heave (right ventricular hypertrophy)
  • Hepatomegaly (right heart failure)
  • Loud systolic murmur (functional tricuspid regurgitation)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary regurgitation: Produces an early diastolic murmur, not systolic

 

Option B. Pulmonary embolism: Usually acute onset, not gradual progression

 

Option C. Pulmonic stenosis: Produces an ejection systolic murmur, but lacks right heart failure features

 

Educational Objective:

 

A triad of chronic dyspnea, left parasternal heave, and hepatomegaly is highly suggestive of pulmonary arterial hypertension.

questions.text: What percentage of increase in FEV1 represents the minimum change required to demonstrate the reversibility of obstruction after administration of bronchodilators in bronchial asthma?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) > 12%

 

Explanation:

 

To diagnose bronchial asthma, it is essential to demonstrate the reversibility of airway obstruction. This is typically assessed by measuring the increase in FEV1 (Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second) after the administration of a bronchodilator.

 

The criteria for significant reversibility in FEV1 are:

 

  • An increase in FEV1 of more than 12% from the baseline.
  • An absolute increase in FEV1 of more than 200 ml.

 

These criteria confirm that the obstruction is reversible, which is a hallmark of asthma.

 

Note - Criterion is used for assessing peak flow rate (PFR) variability is > 20%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A minimum increase of more than 12% in FEV1 after bronchodilator administration is required to demonstrate the reversibility of airway obstruction in bronchial asthma.

questions.text: Which of the following is confirmatory to ensure the central line is in the jugular vein? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chest X-ray

 

A chest X-ray is used to confirm the correct placement of a central line. The tip of the central line should be positioned at the junction of the superior vena cava (SVC) and the right atrium, and this can be confirmed only with a chest X-ray.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ETCO2: Used for confirming endotracheal tube placement.

 

Option B. Blood pH: Not specific for central line placement.

 

Option C. Blood color: Can be misleading and is not confirmatory.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chest X-ray is the gold standard for confirming central line placement in the jugular vein.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presented with follicular tonsillitis, for which antibiotics were prescribed. In a few days, the child developed flank pain and rash. Peripheral blood demonstrated eosinophilia, and urinalysis showed WBC casts. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Allergic Interstitial Nephritis

 

Allergic interstitial nephritis (AIN), also known as drug-induced interstitial nephritis, is an immune-mediated condition commonly caused by medications such as antibiotics (e.g., penicillins). The clinical presentation of AIN typically includes:

 

  • Recent medication use: In this case, antibiotics for follicular tonsillitis.
  • Flank pain and rash: These symptoms often develop a few days after starting the medication.
  • Eosinophilia: Elevated levels of eosinophils in peripheral blood are a hallmark of allergic reactions.
  • Urinalysis findings: Presence of white blood cell (WBC) casts in the urine indicates renal involvement.

 

The combination of these symptoms and laboratory findings strongly suggests allergic interstitial nephritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pyelonephritis: Pyelonephritis is characterized by fever, unilateral flank pain, and urinary symptoms like dysuria. It is usually associated with bacterial infection, not with recent antibiotic use or eosinophilia.

 

Option C. Berger Disease (IgA Nephropathy): IgA nephropathy, or Berger disease, is a glomerulonephritis characterized by hematuria and sometimes proteinuria. It does not typically present with rash, eosinophilia, or WBC casts.

 

Option D. Urinary Tract Infection (UTI): A UTI would present with urinary symptoms such as dysuria, frequency, and urgency. It can also lead to pyelonephritis, but it does not typically cause eosinophilia or WBC casts in the absence of infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Allergic interstitial nephritis is characterized by recent medication use (such as antibiotics), flank pain, rash, eosinophilia, and WBC casts in urine. It is an immune-mediated condition commonly caused by drugs, particularly antibiotics.

questions.text: A wife is complaining that her husband is not taking medications for his diabetes regularly and not maintaining his blood glucose for a long time. Which of the following markers is best for long-duration glucose analysis? (FMGE Jan 2024
questions.solution:
Ans. D) HbA1C

 

Explanation

 

HbA1c, or glycated hemoglobin, is the best marker for assessing long-term glucose control in diabetic patients. It reflects the average blood glucose levels over the past two to three months. This is because glucose binds to hemoglobin in red blood cells, and since red blood cells have a lifespan of about 120 days, the HbA1c value provides a long-term overview of blood glucose levels.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. RBS: Not suitable for long-term glucose control as it only measures blood sugar at a specific moment.

 

Option B. FBS: Provides fasting glucose levels but does not give a long-term picture.

 

Option C. PPBS: Useful for assessing post-meal glucose control but not for long-term analysis.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

HbA1c is the best marker for long-term glucose analysis in diabetic patients as it reflects average blood glucose levels over the past two to three months.

 

The target HbA1c for most patients with diabetes to ensure adequate control is less than 7%, though this may vary based on individual patient circumstances.

questions.text: Which of the following agents is not typically used in the management of chronic hypocalcemia? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Etidronate.

 

Etidronate, a bisphosphonate, is not used in treating chronic hypocalcemia. Bisphosphonates are primarily antiresorptive agents that inhibit osteoclast activity and are indicated for conditions like osteoporosis, Paget's disease, and hypercalcemia. In fact, bisphosphonates can worsen hypocalcemia by reducing bone resorption and calcium release from bone, which is counterproductive in chronic hypocalcemic states.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiazides: This is incorrect because thiazides are actually used in chronic hypocalcemia management. Thiazides reduce urinary calcium excretion (↓Uca) and help increase serum calcium levels (↑S.ca), making them beneficial in hypocalcemic states.

 

Option C. Elemental calcium: This is incorrect because calcium supplementation is the cornerstone of managing chronic hypocalcemia. Oral calcium (carbonate or citrate) is a fundamental component in the treatment regimen for patients with persistent hypocalcemia.

 

Option D. Vitamin D analogs: This is incorrect because vitamin D analogs, particularly calcitriol (1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D), are essential in hypocalcemia management. Calcitriol enhances intestinal calcium absorption and is typically administered alongside calcium supplements.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The management of chronic hypocalcemia centers on calcium replacement (oral calcium), optimization of intestinal calcium absorption (vitamin D analogs/calcitriol), and reduction of urinary calcium excretion (thiazides), while bisphosphonates are contraindicated as they can worsen hypocalcemia.

questions.text: A 43-year-old patient with a history of mitral valve replacement on anticoagulation with warfarin is about to undergo hernioplasty for inguinal hernia. What is the target INR prior to surgery? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1.5

 

Explanation

 

Prior to any major surgery, including abdominal surgeries like hernioplasty, it is crucial to manage the patient's anticoagulation status to minimize the risk of excessive bleeding.

 

For patients on warfarin, the target INR should be brought to less than 1.5 before the surgery.

 

This can be achieved by stopping warfarin and administering vitamin K if necessary.

 

If the INR remains above 1.5 on the day of surgery, fresh frozen plasma (FFP) may be administered to rapidly lower the INR. This approach balances the need to prevent excessive bleeding during surgery while managing the risk of thromboembolic complications.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. 0.5-0.8: This range is too low for general surgical preparation and would indicate a significant reversal of anticoagulation, which is not typically required.

 

Option C. 1.5-2: While this range might be acceptable for some minor procedures, major surgeries generally require an INR of less than 1.5 to ensure safety.

 

Option D. 2-3: This range is appropriate for therapeutic anticoagulation but is too high for surgical procedures due to the increased risk of bleeding.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

For patients on warfarin undergoing major surgery, the target INR should be less than 1.5 to minimize bleeding risk.

choices.text: Occur in the early 20s, rare after 40
More common in males than females

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding Ankylosing Spondylitis are true except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) MRI shows non-erosive joint widening

 

MRI shows non-erosive joint widening: This is false. In ankylosing spondylitis, MRI typically shows evidence of erosions, joint narrowing, and inflammatory changes in the sacroiliac joints and spine. The disease can lead to ankylosis (fusion of the spine), syndesmophytes, and erosive arthropathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is a chronic inflammatory disease that primarily affects the spine and sacroiliac joints. The correct statements regarding AS are:

 

Option A. Occur in the early 20s, rare after 40: Ankylosing spondylitis typically presents in young adults, often in their 20s, and is uncommon after the age of 40.

 

Option B. More common in males than females: AS is more prevalent in males, with a male-to-female ratio of approximately 3:1.

 

Option C. HLA B27 is positive in >90%: Over 90% of patients with AS test positive for the HLA-B27 gene, which is a significant marker for the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MRI findings in ankylosing spondylitis typically show erosive changes and joint narrowing, not non-erosive joint widening.

questions.text: Most common cancer in India in females is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Breast

 

In India, breast cancer is the most common cancer among females. It has surpassed cervical cancer, which previously held the top position. Breast cancer has a high incidence due to various factors, including genetic predisposition, lifestyle changes, and increased awareness leading to higher detection rates. Early detection through screening programs, such as mammography, plays a crucial role in managing and reducing the mortality associated with breast cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cervix: Cervical cancer is the second most common cancer among women in India. It is caused primarily by persistent infection with high-risk human papillomavirus (HPV) types. Despite its high incidence, it is not as common as breast cancer.

 

Option C. Ovary: Ovarian cancer is less common compared to breast and cervical cancers. It often presents at a later stage due to nonspecific symptoms, making it a significant cause of gynecologic cancer mortality.

 

Option D. Endometrium: Endometrial cancer is also less common than breast and cervical cancers in India. It typically occurs in postmenopausal women and is often associated with hormonal imbalances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Breast cancer is the most common cancer among females in India, highlighting the importance of regular screening and early detection to improve outcomes.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female presented with anemia. What is the most common cause? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iron deficiency anemia

 

Iron deficiency anemia is the most common cause of anemia across all age groups, including older adults. It occurs when the body's iron stores are depleted, leading to reduced production of hemoglobin and red blood cells. This condition is especially common in older adults due to factors such as poor dietary intake, gastrointestinal bleeding, and malabsorption.

 

In elderly patients, it is crucial to rule out underlying causes of iron deficiency anemia, particularly gastrointestinal malignancies such as colorectal cancer. For postmenopausal women and elderly men presenting with anemia, investigations such as colonoscopy or fecal occult blood tests are important to identify or exclude potential sources of chronic blood loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anemia of chronic disease: This type of anemia is common in patients with chronic infections, inflammatory diseases, or malignancies, but it is not the most common cause of anemia in the general elderly population.

 

Option C. Aplastic anemia:  A rare condition characterized by pancytopenia and bone marrow failure. It is not a common cause of anemia in the elderly.

 

Option D. Myelodysplastic syndrome:  A group of disorders caused by poorly formed or dysfunctional blood cells, more common in older adults, but not as prevalent as iron deficiency anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron deficiency anemia is the most common cause of anemia, especially in elderly patients, and requires thorough evaluation to rule out serious underlying conditions such as gastrointestinal malignancies.

questions.text: Which brain region's lesion leads to prosopagnosia?(NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Occipito-temporal

 

Prosopagnosia is the inability to recognize faces, which results from lesions in the occipito-temporal cortex, specifically the fusiform face area. This region is specialized for facial recognition and processing. The right hemisphere's fusiform gyrus is particularly critical for this function. When damaged, patients can still see faces normally but cannot identify them as familiar - they may even fail to recognize their own face in a mirror, despite having intact visual perception of other objects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parietal lobe - Lesions here typically cause deficits like hemineglect (right parietal), Gerstmann syndrome (left angular gyrus with agraphia, acalculia, finger agnosia, right-left confusion), or constructional/dressing apraxia, not prosopagnosia.

 

Option B. Frontal lobe - Damage causes executive dysfunction, personality changes, motor deficits, and Broca's aphasia when in the dominant hemisphere. Face recognition remains intact.

 

Option D. Parieto-occipital - While this region is involved in complex visual processing, lesions here typically cause visual spatial deficits like Balint's syndrome rather than specific face recognition problems.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Prosopagnosia results from damage to specialized face-processing regions in the occipito-temporal cortex (fusiform face area), typically following right posterior cerebral artery territory infarcts.

questions.text: A patient presented with fatigue and pallor. Investigations show Hb = 5.8 gm/dl, low ferritin, high TIBC, low MCV, high RDW. Diagnosis is? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iron Deficiency Anemia

 

Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by low hemoglobin levels, low ferritin (indicating depleted iron stores), high total iron-binding capacity (TIBC), low mean corpuscular volume (MCV), and high red cell distribution width (RDW). These laboratory findings are classic for iron deficiency anemia:

 

  • Low ferritin indicates depleted iron stores.
  • High TIBC reflects an increase in the body's attempt to capture more iron due to deficiency.
  • Low MCV signifies microcytic anemia, common in iron deficiency.
  • High RDW indicates variability in red cell size, often seen in iron deficiency as the body produces new, smaller red cells alongside older, larger ones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Megaloblastic Anemia: Typically presents with high MCV (macrocytic anemia) due to deficiency of vitamin B12 or folate, not low MCV.

 

Option C. Anemia of Chronic Disease: Often presents with normal or high ferritin (reflecting inflammation or infection) and low TIBC, not high TIBC.

 

Option D. Sideroblastic Anemia: Generally associated with increased iron stores, not low ferritin, and may show a dimorphic blood picture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron deficiency anemia is indicated by low hemoglobin, low ferritin, high TIBC, low MCV, and high RDW.

questions.text: A patient underwent a major 14-hour-long surgery in the prone position and continues to be on a ventilator during recovery. What is the advantage of Positive End Expiratory Pressure (PEEP) in mechanical ventilation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Reverses atelectasis and prevents collapse

 

Explanation:

 

Positive End Expiratory Pressure (PEEP) is used in mechanical ventilation primarily to keep the alveoli in a partially open state at the end of expiration. This partial inflation increases the Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) of the lungs, which enhances oxygenation and gas exchange. The advantage of keeping alveoli in a partially open state is similar to inflating a partially filled balloon compared to a completely collapsed one; it is much easier to expand a partially filled balloon than one that is fully deflated. This mechanism reduces the work of breathing and prevents the alveoli from completely collapsing, which helps maintain consistent gas exchange and reduces lung trauma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increases CO2 elimination: This is incorrect because PEEP primarily increases oxygenation by preventing alveolar collapse rather than specifically enhancing CO2 elimination.

 

Option C. Increases work of breathing: This is incorrect. PEEP actually reduces the work of breathing by keeping the alveoli partially open, which makes lung inflation easier.

 

Option D. Decreases end expiratory pressure: This is incorrect because PEEP, by definition, increases end-expiratory pressure to prevent alveolar collapse, not decrease it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The main advantage of PEEP in mechanical ventilation is that it helps reverse atelectasis and prevents alveolar collapse, improving oxygenation and reducing the work of breathing.

questions.text: Which of the following causes unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gilbert syndrome

 

Gilbert syndrome is a common hereditary condition characterized by mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. This condition arises due to a partial deficiency of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase, which is responsible for conjugating bilirubin in the liver. As a result, there is an accumulation of unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin in the bloodstream. Patients with Gilbert syndrome often have normal liver function tests and no significant liver pathology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rotor syndrome:  This is a rare hereditary condition that causes conjugated (direct) hyperbilirubinemia due to defects in hepatic storage and excretion of conjugated bilirubin.

 

Option C. Dubin Johnson syndrome: Another hereditary condition that leads to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, characterized by a defect in the excretion of conjugated bilirubin into the bile ducts. The liver cells appear darkly pigmented due to the accumulation of a pigment similar to melanin.

 

Option D. Primary biliary cholangitis: This is an autoimmune disease that causes destruction of the small bile ducts in the liver, leading to cholestasis and conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is associated with elevated alkaline phosphatase levels and the presence of antimitochondrial antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gilbert syndrome causes unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to a partial deficiency of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase, whereas Rotor syndrome, Dubin Johnson syndrome, and primary biliary cholangitis cause conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

questions.text: What is the neoadjuvant therapy used for GIST? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Imatinib

 

Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) are most commonly associated with mutations in the KIT gene or PDGFRA gene. Imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, is used as neoadjuvant therapy for GISTs to shrink the tumor before surgery. This is particularly effective in GISTs with KIT mutations and some PDGFRA mutations.

 

However, not all GISTs respond to imatinib. For instance, GISTs with the PDGFRA D842V mutation or those classified as "wild-type" (lacking KIT or PDGFRA mutations) do not respond well to imatinib. In such cases, surgery is considered the primary treatment option.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prednisolone: Prednisolone is a corticosteroid used in various inflammatory and autoimmune conditions but not typically used for GISTs.

 

Option C. Cyclophosphamide: Cyclophosphamide is an alkylating agent used in certain cancers and autoimmune conditions, but it is not used for GISTs.

 

Option D. Indomethacin:  Indomethacin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used for pain and inflammation but has no role in the treatment of GISTs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Imatinib is the preferred neoadjuvant therapy for GISTs with KIT or certain PDGFRA mutations to reduce tumor size before surgery. It is not effective for all GISTs, particularly those with specific mutations such as PDGFRA D842V or "wild-type" GISTs.

choices.text: It acts as an alkylating agent
It inhibits polymerization of tubulin monomers in mitosis

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of methotrexate in the treatment of cancer? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It inhibits dihydrofolate reductase

 

Methotrexate is an antimetabolite and antifolate drug used in the treatment of various types of cancer. Its primary mechanism of action is the inhibition of the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR). DHFR is crucial for the synthesis of tetrahydrofolate, which is necessary for the synthesis of purines and thymidylate, essential components of DNA. By inhibiting DHFR, methotrexate leads to the depletion of tetrahydrofolate and ultimately inhibits DNA synthesis, cell replication, and cell function, which is particularly effective against rapidly dividing cancer cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acts as an alkylating agent: Alkylating agents work by adding an alkyl group to the DNA molecule, which can lead to DNA strand breaks and cell death. Methotrexate does not work by this mechanism.

 

Option C. Inhibits topoisomerase II: Topoisomerase II inhibitors prevent the DNA from uncoiling and duplicating. Drugs like etoposide and doxorubicin work by this mechanism.

 

Option D. Inhibits polymerization of tubulin monomers in mitosis: This is the mechanism of action of drugs like vincristine and paclitaxel, which interfere with microtubule formation and function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate exerts its anticancer effects primarily by inhibiting the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase, thereby blocking the synthesis of DNA and RNA necessary for cell replication.

questions.text: A 20-year-old boy presented with gum bleeding, easy bruising, and fatigue. He was suffering from fever for 1 month and on examination, he had pallor and a petechial rash distributed all over the body. His peripheral smear revealed macrocytes and his corrected reticulocyte count was 0.5%. Bone marrow revealed few fatty streaks, no immature cells, and no inflammatory cells. What should be the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Idiopathic Acquired Aplastic Anemia

 

The patient's presentation of gum bleeding, easy bruising, fatigue, fever, pallor, and petechial rash suggests Pancytopenia. Pancytopenia can result from several conditions, but the key clues here are:

 

  • Bone marrow findings: The bone marrow shows few fatty streaks, no immature cells, and no inflammatory cells, indicating a hypocellular marrow.
  • Corrected reticulocyte count: A low corrected reticulocyte count (0.5%) indicates poor bone marrow response.

 

These findings are characteristic of idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia, a condition where the bone marrow fails to produce adequate amounts of blood cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Disseminated TB: Disseminated TB usually presents with systemic symptoms and may show a cellular bone marrow due to granulomas and other inflammatory changes, which is not consistent with the findings of a hypocellular marrow.

 

Option C. Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH): PNH typically presents with hemolytic anemia, thrombosis, and sometimes pancytopenia. However, it usually shows a cellular marrow unless it is associated with aplastic anemia. In exams, PNH is generally considered a cause of cellular marrow.

 

Option D. Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS): MDS usually presents with a hypercellular or normocellular marrow with dysplastic changes. It can cause pancytopenia, but the marrow is typically not hypocellular except in rare cases of hypoplastic MDS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia should be considered in patients presenting with pancytopenia, bleeding, bruising, fatigue, and hypocellular bone marrow without significant inflammatory or immature cells. The diagnosis is supported by a low corrected reticulocyte count and clinical findings consistent with bone marrow failure.

questions.text: A patient with suspected tuberculosis underwent CBNAAT testing and is started on HRZE. CBNAAT is helpful for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MTB + Rifampicin resistance

 

Explanation

 

Cartridge-based nucleic acid amplification test (CBNAAT) is a rapid molecular test for the detection of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) and resistance to rifampicin (RIF).

 

It is highly effective for diagnosing tuberculosis and determining rifampicin resistance by detecting mutations in the rpoB gene, which is associated with rifampicin resistance. This allows for quick initiation of appropriate therapy, especially important in cases of drug-resistant TB

 

  • MTB Detection: CBNAAT can confirm the presence of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • Rifampicin Resistance: By identifying rpoB gene mutations, CBNAAT can detect rifampicin resistance, which is a critical factor in managing and treating TB.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB): While CBNAAT detects MTB, it also provides crucial information about rifampicin resistance, making option B more accurate.

 

Option C. MTB + Isoniazid resistance: CBNAAT does not detect isoniazid resistance directly.

 

Option D. MTB + Ethambutol and Rifampicin: CBNAAT does not provide information about ethambutol resistance.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

CBNAAT is a rapid and effective test for detecting Mycobacterium tuberculosis and rifampicin resistance by identifying mutations in the rpoB gene.

questions.text: In primary accidental hypothermia, what is the usual rate of rewarming with passive external rewarming?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 0.5-2°C per hour

 

Explanation

 

Primary accidental hypothermia refers to an unintentional drop in core body temperature due to environmental exposure. The management of hypothermia includes rewarming strategies, which can be classified into passive and active rewarming.

 

Passive External Rewarming: This method involves insulating the patient by covering them with blankets and ensuring that the head is also covered. It relies on the patient's own heat production to gradually increase body temperature.

 

According to standard medical guidelines and Harrison's principles, passive external rewarming can increase the core body temperature by approximately 0.5 to 2°C per hour.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

In cases of primary accidental hypothermia, passive external rewarming can raise the core body temperature by 0.5 to 2°C per hour.

 

Additional Information –

 

Hypothermia based on core body temperature and corresponding treatment methods:

 

  1. Mild Hypothermia:
    • Core Body Temperature: Less than 35 degrees Celsius.
    • Treatment: Passive external rewarming is the treatment of choice.
  2. Moderate Hypothermia:
    • Core Body Temperature: Less than 32 degrees Celsius.
    • Treatment: Requires both passive and active rewarming methods. Passive rewarming involves external methods, while active rewarming can be either external or internal.
  3. Severe Hypothermia
    • Core Body Temperature: Less than 28 degrees Celsius.
    • Treatment: Requires both passive and active rewarming methods. Passive rewarming involves external methods, while active rewarming can be either external or internal.

questions.text: A patient presents with uveitis and sacroiliitis. What is most likely associated with it? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HLA B27

 

The presentation of uveitis along with sacroiliitis is a classic manifestation of seronegative spondyloarthropathy, which is strongly associated with HLA-B27. These conditions are characterized by:

 

  • Inflammatory back pain
  • Early morning stiffness lasting more than one hour
  • Pain and stiffness that improve with exercise and worsen with rest
  • Anterior uveitis as the most common extra-articular manifestation
  • Sacroiliitis
  • Peripheral arthritis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HLA B8: Incorrect. Associated with good prognosis in sarcoidosis, not spondyloarthropathy

 

Option C. HLA B5: Incorrect. Associated with Behçet's disease

 

Option D. HLA B51: Incorrect. Also associated with Behçet's disease

 

Educational Objective:

 

HLA-B27 is strongly associated with seronegative spondyloarthropathies, particularly when patients present with the combination of uveitis and sacroiliitis.

questions.text: What is the lowest detection limit for third-generation TSH assays? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 0.004 mIU/L

 

The third-generation TSH immunochemiluminometric assays (ICMAs) have extremely high sensitivity, capable of detecting very low TSH levels. Extremely sensitive assays can detect TSH levels ≤0.004 mIU/L, though for practical clinical purposes, assays sensitive to ≤0.1 mIU/L are generally sufficient. This high sensitivity is what allows these modern assays to discriminate between the lower limit of the normal range and the suppressed values seen in thyrotoxicosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 0.04 mIU/L: This value is incorrect as it is 10 times higher than the actual detection limit of third-generation TSH assays, which can detect levels down to 0.004 mIU/L.

 

Option B. 0.1 mIU/L: This represents the practical sensitivity threshold that is considered sufficient for most clinical purposes, but is not the actual detection limit of third-generation assays.

 

Option D. 0.0044 mIU/L: This value is incorrect. The detection limit for extremely sensitive third-generation TSH assays is 0.004 mIU/L.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Third-generation TSH immunochemiluminometric assays can detect TSH levels as low as 0.004 mIU/L, which is essential for discriminating between the lower limit of the normal reference range and the suppressed values found in thyrotoxicosis, though for most clinical applications, assays with sensitivity to 0.1 mIU/L are adequate.

choices.text: CT pulmonary angiogram

questions.text: An elderly male on bed rest for many months presented with breathlessness and chest pain. What is the next best step in the management of this patient? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CT pulmonary angiogram

 

The patient has a history of prolonged immobilization and presents with symptoms of breathlessness and pleuritic chest pain, which are suggestive of pulmonary embolism (PE). Prolonged bed rest is a significant risk factor for PE due to venous stasis and the potential for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) to embolize to the lungs.

 

A CT pulmonary angiogram is the gold standard diagnostic test for acute pulmonary embolism. It provides a detailed image of the pulmonary arteries and can identify the presence of emboli.

 

Screening test – D-dimer

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ECG: While an ECG can be performed to check for any cardiac abnormalities, the most common finding in PE is sinus tachycardia, which is not specific. It will not confirm the diagnosis of PE.

 

Option C. CT thorax: A CT thorax without angiogram will not provide the necessary details to diagnose PE.

 

Option D. Echocardiography: Echocardiography can show right ventricular dysfunction, which may suggest PE, but it is not definitive for diagnosing PE. It is more useful for assessing the cardiac impact of an established PE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The CT pulmonary angiogram is the gold standard investigation for confirming pulmonary embolism.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used for cancers can cause hand-foot syndrome? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Capecitabine

 

Hand-foot syndrome, also known as palmar-plantar erythrodysesthesia, is a side effect of certain chemotherapy drugs. It is characterized by redness, swelling, and pain on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet. This condition is most commonly associated with pyrimidine analogs, such as 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) and its prodrug capecitabine. Capecitabine is a widely used chemotherapeutic agent for various cancers, including colorectal and breast cancer, and is well known for causing hand-foot syndrome as a dose-limiting toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cyclophosphamide:  This is an alkylating agent used in cancer treatment and does not typically cause hand-foot syndrome.

 

Option B. Bleomycin:  An antitumor antibiotic used in cancer therapy, primarily associated with pulmonary toxicity rather than hand-foot syndrome.

 

Option C. Paclitaxel: A microtubule inhibitor used in cancer treatment, which can cause peripheral neuropathy and hypersensitivity reactions, but is not commonly associated with hand-foot syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Capecitabine, a pyrimidine analog, is the cancer drug most commonly associated with causing hand-foot syndrome, characterized by redness, swelling, and pain in the hands and feet.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady presented with generalized fatigue and lethargy. Her general examination revealed a few superficial lymph nodes in the cervical and axillary regions. Labs – TC: 7400, Hb: 12.8 g/dL, and Platelets: 244,000. She had a normal DC and lymph node biopsy revealed architectural distortion, infiltration with cells with indented nucleus, and prominent nucleolus containing atypical cells. Immunophenotyping showed CD10 and Bcl2 were positive. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Follicular Lymphoma

 

The diagnosis of follicular lymphoma is supported by several key features in this patient's presentation and pathology findings:

 

  • Architectural distortion and infiltration with atypical cells: These findings on lymph node biopsy are consistent with follicular lymphoma.
  • Immunophenotyping: The presence of CD10 and Bcl2 positivity is characteristic of follicular lymphoma. CD10 is a marker indicating origin from the germinal center, and Bcl2 positivity suggests the presence of the anti-apoptotic protein Bcl2, which is a hallmark of follicular lymphoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Burkitt Lymphoma: Burkitt lymphoma is associated with c-myc overexpression due to the t(8;14) translocation. It often presents with a high proliferation index and does not typically express Bcl2.

 

Option B. Hodgkin Lymphoma: Hodgkin lymphoma is characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells. Sometime, PD1 overexpression. Immunophenotyping usually shows CD15 and CD30 positivity, not CD10 and Bcl2.

 

Option C. Mantle Cell Lymphoma: Mantle cell lymphoma is characterized by cyclin D1 overexpression due to the t(11;14) translocation. It is usually CD5 and cyclin D1 positive, not CD10 and Bcl2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Follicular lymphoma often presents with lymphadenopathy and generalized symptoms such as fatigue. Key diagnostic features include CD10 and Bcl2 positivity on immunophenotyping, reflecting its germinal center origin and overexpression of the anti-apoptotic protein Bcl2.

questions.text: Which of the following can be prevented by folic acid supplementation in pregnancy? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neural tube defects

 

Folic acid supplementation before conception and during early pregnancy significantly reduces the risk of neural tube defects (NTDs) in the developing fetus. Neural tube defects are serious birth defects of the brain and spine, such as spina bifida and anencephaly. Adequate folic acid intake is crucial during the early stages of pregnancy, often before a woman even knows she is pregnant, which is why supplementation is recommended for all women of childbearing age.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anemia: While folic acid can help in the prevention of certain types of anemia, such as megaloblastic anemia, it is not the primary preventive measure for anemia during pregnancy, which is more commonly addressed with iron supplementation.

 

Option B. Preeclampsia: Preeclampsia is a pregnancy complication characterized by high blood pressure and damage to other organ systems. There is no strong evidence that folic acid supplementation alone can prevent preeclampsia.

 

Option D. Gestational diabetes: Gestational diabetes is a type of diabetes that develops during pregnancy. Folic acid supplementation is not known to prevent gestational diabetes; its primary preventive role is in reducing the risk of neural tube defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Folic acid supplementation before and during early pregnancy is essential to prevent neural tube defects in the developing fetus.

questions.text: A 40-year-old electrical worker is brought to the emergency department after sustaining a high-voltage electric shock at work. He reports muscle pain, weakness, and dark-colored urine since the incident. Physical examination reveals tender, swollen muscles in the upper limbs. What is the most likely substance found in his urine? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Myoglobin

 

Explanation:

 

This patient presents with rhabdomyolysis following a high-voltage electrical injury, characterized by:

 

  • Muscle pain, weakness, and dark-colored urine (myoglobinuria)
  • Elevated creatine kinase (CK) levels
  • Tender, swollen muscles

 

Myoglobin is released into circulation from damaged muscle cells and subsequently filtered by the kidneys, leading to myoglobinuria, which can cause acute kidney injury (AKI) due to tubular toxicity and obstruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RBCs: Would indicate hematuria, which is not the main feature of rhabdomyolysis

 

Option C. Creatine kinase: Although CK levels are elevated, CK is not excreted in urine

 

Option D. Bilirubin: Suggests liver dysfunction or hemolysis, not muscle breakdown

 

Educational Objective:

 

In rhabdomyolysis, myoglobin is released from damaged muscles, leading to myoglobinuria and a risk of acute kidney injury.

questions.text: A patient presents with an intense headache, repeated vomiting, and neck stiffness. Lumbar puncture yields turbid cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). Microscopic analysis shows 90% polymorphonuclear leukocytes, a CSF glucose of 40 mg/dL (serum glucose: 120 mg/dL), and a protein concentration of 200 mg/dL. What is the most suitable treatment approach for this patient? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ceftriaxone plus vancomycin

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation and CSF findings strongly suggest bacterial meningitis, characterized by:

 

  • Headache, vomiting, neck stiffness (classic triad)
  • Turbid CSF with neutrophilic pleocytosis (90% PMNs)
  • Low CSF glucose (<50% of serum glucose)
  • Elevated protein (>45 mg/dL)

 

Empirical treatment for adult bacterial meningitis:

 

  • Ceftriaxone – Covers Neisseria meningitidis and most pneumococci
  • Vancomycin – Added to cover resistant Streptococcus pneumoniae

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HRZE (anti-TB therapy): Used for tuberculous meningitis, which presents with chronic symptoms and lymphocytic pleocytosis

 

Option B. Ceftriaxone + acyclovir: Used for HSV encephalitis, which shows lymphocytic pleocytosis and temporal lobe involvement

 

Option D. Cefotaxime + ampicillin: Used in neonatal, elderly, or immunocompromised patients (for Listeria monocytogenes)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bacterial meningitis treatment involves empiric ceftriaxone + vancomycin to cover resistant pneumococci and meningococci.

questions.text: A pregnant female who is a known case of bronchial asthma presented to the hospital with blood pressure of 210/110 mm Hg. Which of the following is the preferred drug for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nifedipine

 

Explanation

 

In managing hypertension in a pregnant patient with a history of bronchial asthma, the choice of antihypertensive medication is critical due to the contraindications of certain drug classes in both pregnancy and asthma.

 

Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker that is considered safe in pregnancy and does not cause bronchoconstriction, making it the preferred choice for hypertensive management in a pregnant patient with asthma.

 

Nicardipine, another calcium channel blocker, can also be used, especially in IV form, but nifedipine is often chosen due to its safety profile and efficacy.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Oral Labetalol and Option C. IV Labetalol: Contraindicated in asthma due to bronchoconstriction. These drugs can exacerbate bronchial asthma by causing bronchoconstriction, making them unsuitable for patients with asthma.

 

Option D. Ramipril: ACE inhibitors like Ramipril are contraindicated in pregnancy due to their association with fetal toxicity, including renal damage and oligohydramnios

 

Educational Objectives:

 

For hypertensive management in a pregnant patient with bronchial asthma, nifedipine is the preferred drug due to its safety in pregnancy and lack of bronchoconstrictive effects.

questions.text: Which of the following is most indicative of chronic renal failure? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Broad waxy cast.

 

Explanation:

 

Broad waxy casts are characteristic findings in chronic kidney disease/chronic renal failure. These casts appear in the urine sediment when there is severe, long-standing tubular damage and reduced urine flow. Waxy casts are homogeneous, have a low refractive index, and often display cracked or broken edges, resembling candle wax. Their presence indicates significant tubular atrophy and interstitial fibrosis, hallmarks of chronic kidney disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyaline cast: Hyaline casts are composed primarily of Tamm-Horsfall mucoprotein and can be found in normal urine, especially after exercise. They may also appear with mild tubular dysfunction, dehydration, or concentrated urine, but are not specific for chronic renal failure.

 

Option B. Coarse granular cast: Coarse granular casts contain degenerating cellular debris and typically indicate active kidney injury. They are seen in acute tubular necrosis and other acute kidney injuries rather than chronic disease.

 

Option D. Epithelial cast: Epithelial casts contain shed renal tubular epithelial cells and indicate acute tubular damage. They are found in conditions such as acute tubular necrosis, viral infections affecting the kidney, or drug toxicity, not chronic renal failure.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Broad waxy casts in urinary sediment are pathognomonic for chronic kidney disease and represent advanced, long-standing tubular damage and significantly reduced urinary flow.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of Rivaroxaban? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Factor X inhibitor

 

Rivaroxaban is an oral anticoagulant that functions as a direct Factor Xa inhibitor. Factor Xa plays a crucial role in the coagulation cascade, leading to the conversion of prothrombin to thrombin, which subsequently forms fibrin clots. By inhibiting Factor Xa, Rivaroxaban effectively prevents the formation of thrombin and subsequent clot formation, providing anticoagulant effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Direct Thrombin inhibitor: Drugs that act as direct thrombin inhibitors include Dabigatran, Argatroban, Bivalirudin, and Lepirudin. These drugs directly inhibit thrombin, preventing the conversion of fibrinogen to fibrin.

 

Option C. Increased ATIII activity: This mechanism is associated with heparins and heparinoids. These drugs enhance the activity of antithrombin III (ATIII), which inactivates thrombin and other proteases involved in blood clotting.

 

Option D. Vitamin K inhibition: Warfarin and other coumarin derivatives inhibit the synthesis of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors (II, VII, IX, and X) by inhibiting vitamin K epoxide reductase. This reduces the body's ability to form clots.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rivaroxaban is a direct Factor Xa inhibitor, which prevents the formation of thrombin and subsequent clot formation in the coagulation cascade.

questions.text: Which of the following is used as a diagnostic test for CML? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) FISH

 

Explanation

 

Fluorescent In-Situ Hybridization (FISH) is the gold standard for diagnosing Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML). This test detects the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome, which is the result of a translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22, creating the BCR-ABL fusion gene. This fusion gene produces a protein with abnormal tyrosine kinase activity, which drives the pathogenesis of CML.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Bone marrow Aspiration: While it can show increased cellularity and myeloid hyperplasia, i.e. help in assessing the extent of disease and marrow involvement but is not definitive for diagnosing CML.

 

Option C. LAP score: Low in CML but also low in other conditions, hence not specific.

 

Option D. Karyotyping: While it can detect chromosomal abnormalities, it is less sensitive compared to FISH for detecting the BCR-ABL fusion gene.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Fluorescent In-Situ Hybridization (FISH) is the gold standard diagnostic test for Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) because it specifically identifies the BCR-ABL fusion gene.

questions.text: Splenectomy is contraindicated in which of the following conditions? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bone marrow failure

 

Bone marrow failure often seen in aplastic anemia, involves the failure of the bone marrow to produce sufficient blood cells. The spleen is not involved in this pathology, so splenectomy would not be beneficial. The problem lies within the bone marrow, not the spleen, making splenectomy contraindicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Splenic rupture: Splenectomy is commonly indicated in cases of splenic rupture, whether due to trauma or iatrogenic causes, to prevent life-threatening hemorrhage.

 

Option B. Thrombocytopenia: In cases of idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), splenectomy can be an effective treatment option to achieve durable remission, although it is not the first-line treatment.

 

  • Corticosteroids and other treatments are often tried first.

 

Option C. Hairy cell leukemia: Splenectomy may be indicated in hairy cell leukemia in cases of massive splenomegaly or persistent cytopenias to alleviate symptoms and improve blood counts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Splenectomy is contraindicated in bone marrow failure, as the underlying issue resides in the bone marrow's inability to produce blood cells.

questions.text: A young boy presents with a platelet count of 10,000/μL. Bone marrow aspirate reveals normal cellularity with increased number of megakaryocytes. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this condition? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG)

 

This clinical presentation is consistent with immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP). The key features include severe thrombocytopenia (platelet count 10,000/μL), normal bone marrow cellularity with increased megakaryocytes, indicating peripheral platelet destruction rather than production failure. In patients with life-threatening thrombocytopenia or severe bleeding in ITP, intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) is the first-line treatment. IVIG works by blocking or saturating macrophage Fc receptors, providing faster response (24-48 hours) compared to corticosteroids. In non-bleeding patients without urgent symptoms, corticosteroids would be the first-line treatment, but given the severely low platelet count, IVIG is more appropriate for immediate management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methotrexate: This immunosuppressive agent is not used in the initial treatment of ITP. It may be considered as a second-line or third-line agent in refractory cases, but it is not appropriate for initial management, especially in a young patient with severe thrombocytopenia.

 

Option C. Bone Marrow Transplant: This is not indicated in ITP since the condition involves peripheral destruction of platelets rather than bone marrow failure. The bone marrow is functioning normally with increased megakaryocyte production, making transplantation unnecessary and inappropriate.

 

Option D. Aspirin: This would be contraindicated in a patient with severe thrombocytopenia as it would further impair platelet function and significantly increase bleeding risk. Aspirin inhibits platelet aggregation, which would be dangerous in someone with already critically low platelet counts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In ITP with severe thrombocytopenia and bleeding risk, IVIG provides rapid response by blocking macrophage Fc receptors and is the preferred initial treatment.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient complained of bilateral lower limb numbness. He has a history of low BP and gastrectomy done for gastric cancer a year back. On examination, Romberg test is positive and there is loss of proprioception in both lower limbs. Which of the following deficiency can cause this condition? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B12 deficiency

 

This patient's presentation strongly suggests Vitamin B12 deficiency for several reasons:

 

  1. History of gastrectomy – Loss of stomach leads to loss of intrinsic factor, essential for B12 absorption
  2. Neurological symptoms – Bilateral lower limb numbness
  3. Positive Romberg test and loss of proprioception indicate posterior column involvement, which is characteristic of subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord seen in B12 deficiency
  4. The combination of gastrectomy and neurological symptoms is classic for B12 deficiency

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B6 deficiency: While it can cause peripheral neuropathy, it doesn't typically cause posterior column signs

 

Option C. Thiamine deficiency: Primarily causes Wernicke's encephalopathy and cardiovascular symptoms; doesn't typically present with proprioception loss; more commonly seen in alcoholics

 

Option D. Folic acid deficiency: Primarily causes hematological manifestations; does not cause neurological symptoms like B12 deficiency

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastrectomy leads to B12 deficiency due to loss of intrinsic factor, and B12 deficiency can cause subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, presenting with posterior column signs (proprioception loss and positive Romberg test).

questions.text: All are hereditary causes of thrombosis except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PNH (Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria)

 

PNH is an acquired stem cell disorder, not a hereditary condition. It occurs due to a somatic mutation in the PIG-A gene that produces GPI (glycosyl phosphatidylinositol) anchors. This defect affects proteins CD55 and CD59 (also known as DAF and MIRL respectively), which are important complement regulatory proteins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Protein C deficiency: Hereditary cause of thrombosis; Protein C is a natural anticoagulant

 

Option C. Factor V Leiden mutation: Most common inherited cause of thrombophilia

 

Option D. Antithrombin III deficiency: Inherited condition increasing thrombotic risk

 

Educational Objective:

 

PNH is an acquired (not hereditary) stem cell disorder caused by somatic mutations in the PIG-A gene. Protein C deficiency, Factor V Leiden mutation, and Antithrombin III deficiency are hereditary causes of thrombophilia.

questions.text: A patient presented with Ventricular Tachycardia. What is the best drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amiodarone

 

Explanation

 

For treating ventricular tachycardia (VT), the drug of choice in acute situations according to Advanced Life Support (ALS) protocols is Amiodarone. It is a class III antiarrhythmic medication that works by prolonging the action potential duration and refractory period in the myocardial cells, thus stabilizing the cardiac rhythm.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Adenosine: Ineffective for ventricular tachycardia as it is primarily used for supraventricular tachycardia.

 

Option C. Propranolol: A beta-blocker used for various cardiac conditions, but not typically effective for acute VT.

 

Option D. Ivabradine: Used to reduce heart rate in chronic heart failure and stable angina, not suitable for VT management

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Amiodarone is the best drug for the acute management of ventricular tachycardia due to its efficacy in stabilizing cardiac rhythm by prolonging the action potential and refractory period in myocardial cells.

questions.text: What blood group can be transfused to an individual with Bombay blood group? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oh

 

The Bombay blood group, also known as the Oh blood group, is a rare blood type that lacks the H antigen, which is present in all other blood types. Individuals with the Bombay blood group have antibodies against the H antigen, which means they cannot receive blood from any of the common ABO blood groups, including the universal donor O blood group, as it contains the H antigen. Transfusing blood that contains the H antigen to someone with the Bombay blood group would lead to a severe hemolytic reaction. Therefore, individuals with the Bombay blood group can only receive blood from other Bombay blood group donors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AB negative: This blood group contains the H antigen and would cause a hemolytic reaction in a Bombay blood group individual.

 

Option B. B: This blood group also contains the H antigen, making it incompatible with the Bombay blood group.

 

Option D. O negative: Although O negative is considered a universal donor in the context of the ABO and Rh systems, it still contains the H antigen and is therefore not compatible with the Bombay blood group.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Individuals with the Bombay blood group (Oh) can only receive blood from other Bombay blood group donors due to the presence of anti-H antibodies.

choices.text: Ventilation perfusion scan of lungs

questions.text: A resident is evaluating a patient, who presented with acute onset of chest pain and dyspnea, for pulmonary embolism. Which of the following imaging test should be performed to confirm this diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CT pulmonary angiography

 

CT pulmonary angiography is the gold standard imaging test for diagnosing pulmonary embolism, providing detailed images of the pulmonary arteries. It is highly sensitive and specific for detecting emboli.

 

Note - D-dimer test is used as an initial screening tool. Elevated levels of D-dimer can suggest the presence of a thrombus, but it is not specific and can be elevated in various other conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Doppler echocardiography: Can show right heart strain but is not definitive for diagnosing PE.

 

Option C. Ventilation perfusion scan of lungs: Used when CT angiography is contraindicated but less specific.

 

Option D. MR pulmonary angiography: Less commonly used and not the first-line diagnostic tool.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CT pulmonary angiography is the gold standard for diagnosing pulmonary embolism.

choices.text: Decreased action of LPL and increased action of HSL
Increased action of LPL and increased action of HSL
Decreased action of LPL and decreased action of HSL
Increased action of LPL and decreased action of HSL

questions.text: In a patient with diabetes mellitus, the synthesis of TG and VLDL is increased from the liver. What is the cause of the same? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreased action of LPL and increased action of HSL

 

In diabetes mellitus, insulin deficiency or resistance leads to two important enzymatic changes:

 

  1. Decreased activity of Lipoprotein Lipase (LPL) – This enzyme normally converts triglycerides in blood to free fatty acids for storage in adipose tissue
  2. Increased activity of Hormone Sensitive Lipase (HSL) – This promotes release of stored triglycerides as free fatty acids from adipose tissue

 

These changes result in:

 

  • Increased triglycerides in blood due to decreased LPL activity
  • Increased lipolysis and ketosis due to increased HSL activity
  • Overall increase in circulating free fatty acids

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increased action of LPL and increased action of HSL: Insulin resistance/deficiency decreases LPL activity

 

Option C. Decreased action of LPL and decreased action of HSL: HSL activity is increased, not decreased in diabetes

 

Option D. Increased action of LPL and decreased action of HSL: This would increase TG clearance and decrease lipolysis, opposite to what occurs in diabetes

 

Educational Objective:

 

In diabetes mellitus, decreased LPL and increased HSL activities lead to increased triglycerides and VLDL synthesis in the liver, contributing to diabetic dyslipidemia.

questions.text: A patient was given 0.5% bupivacaine for supraclavicular brachial plexus block and suddenly developed hypotension and arrhythmias. Which of the following is the first line of management? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 20% IV Intralipid

 

Explanation

 

The patient experienced toxicity due to bupivacaine, a local anesthetic. The first-line treatment for local anesthetic toxicity, including bupivacaine toxicity, is the administration of 20% IV intralipid (lipid emulsion therapy). This treatment works by acting as a "lipid sink," which helps to absorb the lipophilic local anesthetic molecules and reduce their toxic effects on the cardiovascular and central nervous systems.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. IV Epinephrine: Suitable for cardiac arrest but not the first line for local anesthetic toxicity.

 

Option C. IV Soda Bicarbonate: Used in cases of tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) toxicity causing ventricular arrhythmias but not for local anesthetic toxicity.

 

Option D. IV Dobutamine: Used to treat heart failure and certain types of shock, but not specifically for local anesthetic toxicity

 

Educational Objectives:

 

The first-line treatment for bupivacaine toxicity is the administration of 20% IV intralipid (lipid emulsion therapy).

questions.text: The observed myocardial stunning pattern does not match the ECG findings of a patient. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Takotsubo cardiomyopathy

 

 

Stress cardiomyopathy commonly affects Women (post-menopausal) > men predominantly due to emotional > physical stress. Neurogenic myocardial stunning occurs leading to heart failure.

 

Beta-2 (Gs stimulation) is present at base and b2 (Gi) activation leads to hypercontractility at the base & apical ballooning giving a typical Takotsubo appearance.

 

ECG mimics ACS, RWMA not corresponding to single artery territory, normal CAG with Mild troponin elevation are clues to takotsubo.

 

Treatment with beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors if non-responsive. Carries good prognosis.

 

Other options:

 

Option B: Restrictive cardiomyopathy causes diastolic dysfunction on but NOT significant ECG changes.

 

Option C: Brugada syndrome is a channelopathy caused due LOF (loss of function) mutation of cardiac SCN5a (Sodium channel) resulting in transmural voltage difference between endocardium-epicardium causing ventricular arrhythmias which initially affects the RV myocardium.

 

 

Option D: Tamponade occurs due to rapid accumulation of fluid/blood in the pericardium producing the characteristic Beck triad (↑JVP ↓ Heart sounds ↓ BP).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy should be considered when a patient's clinical presentation includes myocardial stunning that does not correspond to ECG findings typical of a myocardial infarction, especially in the context of recent significant emotional or physical stress.

 

Reference - Harrison/Cardiology/Cardiomyopathies/Chap 259

questions.text: A dwarf female patient brought to the hospital with a history of primary amenorrhea, webbed neck, and widely placed nipples. What is the most common karyotype associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 45X0

 

Explanation

 

The presentation of a dwarf female patient with primary amenorrhea, webbed neck, and widely spaced nipples is characteristic of Turner syndrome. Turner syndrome is a chromosomal disorder caused by complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome, most commonly represented by the karyotype 45X0. This syndrome is the most common cause of primary amenorrhea.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Turner syndrome, characterized by the karyotype 45X0, is the most common chromosomal disorder associated with features such as primary amenorrhea, webbed neck, and widely spaced nipples in females.

questions.text: A patient presented with recurrent Raynaud’s phenomenon. She also complained of thickening of skin in the hands and difficulty in swallowing. What is the diagnosis and immunofluorescence pattern shown? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anti-centromere pattern; Systemic sclerosis

 

The combination of Raynaud's phenomenon, skin thickening limited to hands (acral areas), and difficulty swallowing points to limited systemic sclerosis (formerly called CREST syndrome). The immunofluorescence image shows a characteristic centromeric pattern with discrete speckles corresponding to centromeres in dividing cells. Anti-centromere antibodies are specifically associated with limited systemic sclerosis, making this pattern diagnostic in this clinical context.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nuclear pattern; SLE: Incorrect. The pattern shown is centromeric, not nuclear.

 

Option B. Homogeneous pattern; SLE: Incorrect. Homogeneous patterns are produced by anti-histone and anti-dsDNA antibodies, seen in SLE or drug-induced lupus.

 

Option C. Speckled pattern; Systemic sclerosis: Incorrect. While speckled patterns can be seen in systemic sclerosis (particularly with anti-Scl-70 antibodies in diffuse disease), the image shows a centromeric pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-centromere antibodies producing a centromeric immunofluorescence pattern are specifically associated with limited systemic sclerosis, particularly when presenting with Raynaud's phenomenon and acral skin thickening.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman visits the outpatient clinic complaining of pain, fatigue, and weakness in both lower limbs. She reports a history of childhood paralysis affecting both lower limbs, from which she had a good functional recovery. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Post-Polio Syndrome

 

Post-Polio Syndrome (PPS) is characterized by new weakness, fatigue, and pain that develops decades after an initial episode of paralytic poliomyelitis from which the patient had at least partial recovery. The patient's history of childhood paralysis affecting both lower limbs with good functional recovery, followed by new symptoms of pain, fatigue, and weakness in the same distribution decades later (now at age 45) is the classic presentation of PPS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Polymyositis: Polymyositis typically presents with subacute onset of symmetric proximal muscle weakness without a prior history of paralysis. It does not follow a pattern of recurrence after decades of stability. The inflammatory myopathies like polymyositis are characterized by elevated muscle enzymes, characteristic EMG findings, and muscle biopsy showing inflammation, which are not mentioned in this case. The history of childhood paralysis with good recovery followed by late deterioration is not consistent with polymyositis.

 

Option C. Muscular Dystrophy: Muscular dystrophies are inherited disorders with progressive weakness that typically begins in childhood or early adulthood. They do not present with an episode of paralysis followed by recovery and then delayed deterioration decades later. Most muscular dystrophies show a pattern of continuous progression rather than the biphasic course described in this patient.

 

Option D. Neuropathy: Peripheral neuropathies typically present with distal weakness, sensory symptoms, and often absent reflexes. While some neuropathies can affect the lower limbs predominantly, the history of childhood paralysis with recovery followed by late deterioration is not characteristic of most neuropathies. Additionally, neuropathies often have sensory symptoms which aren't prominent in this case.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Post-polio syndrome presents as new weakness, fatigue, and pain occurring decades after recovery from acute paralytic poliomyelitis, typically affecting the same muscle groups that were originally involved.

choices.text: Subacute Combined Degeneration of the Spinal Cord

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy arrives at the outpatient clinic with a history of progressively worsening difficulty in walking and frequent episodes of falling. Physical examination shows an ataxic gait with absent deep tendon reflexes. The Babinski sign is negative, and the plantar reflex demonstrates an extensor response. Which diagnosis is most likely? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Friedreich's Ataxia

 

Friedreich's ataxia is characterized by progressive cerebellar ataxia, absent deep tendon reflexes, and pyramidal signs. The clinical presentation of a 12-year-old boy with progressively worsening gait difficulty, ataxia, and absent deep tendon reflexes strongly suggests this diagnosis. Friedreich's ataxia typically presents in childhood or adolescence (before age 25) and affects the posterior columns, spinocerebellar tracts, and corticospinal tracts, leading to the combination of sensory ataxia and pyramidal signs. The loss of deep tendon reflexes reflects peripheral sensory neuronopathy, while extensor plantar responses indicate corticospinal tract involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option Subacute Combined Degeneration: While this also affects posterior columns and corticospinal tracts, it's caused by vitamin B12 deficiency and typically presents in adults. It would show increased, not absent, deep tendon reflexes.

 

Option Becker's Muscular Dystrophy: This dystrophinopathy presents with proximal muscle weakness rather than ataxia. Reflexes would be preserved until late in the disease, and there would be no sensory involvement or extensor plantar responses.

 

Option Tabes Dorsalis: This manifestation of tertiary syphilis is extremely rare in children. While it causes sensory ataxia and areflexia, it lacks pyramidal signs (would not have extensor plantar responses) and would be highly unusual in a 12-year-old.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The combination of progressive ataxia, absent deep tendon reflexes, and extensor plantar responses in an adolescent is the classic presentation of Friedreich's ataxia, reflecting the disease's characteristic involvement of multiple spinal cord pathways.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic presented with pruritic eczematous rash on the neck and dorsum of hands. What is the likely nutritional deficiency?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B3

 

Explanation

 

Chronic alcoholics are prone to multiple nutrient deficiencies due to malnourishment and malnutrition. The given history is compatible with a disease called Pellagra, which is due to Niacin (Vitamin B3) deficiency. Pellagra is characterized by the "3 D's": Diarrhea, Dermatitis, and Dementia, and it can also lead to death, sometimes referred to as the "4 D's."

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Vitamin B1: Causes Wernicke's encephalopathy, peripheral neuropathy, and heart failure but does not match the described skin condition.

 

Option C. Vitamin D: Associated with rickets and osteomalacia, not pruritic eczematous rash.

 

Option D. Vitamin C: Causes scurvy with gum bleeding and other symptoms, not the described dermatitis.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Pellagra, characterized by the "3 D's" (Diarrhea, Dermatitis, Dementia), is caused by Vitamin B3 (Niacin) deficiency and is commonly seen in chronic alcoholics.

questions.text: A patient presents with severe pain and swelling in his knee joint for 10 days. He also complains of pain and discomfort during urination. He says that he had diarrhea one month ago and has been unwell since then. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Reactive arthritis

 

Reactive arthritis typically follows a gastrointestinal or genitourinary infection and presents with arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis (Reiter's syndrome). The patient's history of diarrhea one month ago and current symptoms of joint pain and urethritis are classic signs.

 

Reactive Arthritis is a type of inflammatory arthritis that typically occurs following an infection. Here’s a summary of its key points:

 

  • Common Triggers:
    • Gastrointestinal Infections: Often caused by bacteria such as Shigella.
    • Genitourinary Infections: Most commonly associated with non-gonococcal urethritis, particularly due to Chlamydia.
  • Classic Triad of Symptoms:
    • Arthritis: Joint inflammation and pain.
    • Conjunctivitis: Eye inflammation.
    • Urethritis: Inflammation of the urethra.

 

Mnemonic: The classic triad is summarized as "Can't see, can't pee, can't climb a tree."

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Enteropathic arthritis: Associated with inflammatory bowel diseases like Crohn's and UC, without preceding infection.

 

Option C. Rheumatoid arthritis: Chronic, symmetrical joint involvement, not typically post-infectious.

 

Option D. Psoriatic arthritis: Associated with psoriasis, not a preceding infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reactive arthritis follows gastrointestinal or genitourinary infections and presents with arthritis, urethritis, and sometimes conjunctivitis.

questions.text: What is Gaisböck syndrome? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Relative polycythemia

 

Gaisböck syndrome, also known as stress polycythemia or pseudopolycythemia, is a condition characterized by an apparent increase in the red blood cell (RBC) mass due to a reduction in plasma volume, typically caused by dehydration. This leads to an elevated hematocrit and hemoglobin concentration without an actual increase in the total number of red blood cells. The condition is termed "relative polycythemia" because the increase in RBC concentration is relative to the decreased plasma volume rather than an absolute increase in RBC production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Absolute polycythemia: Absolute polycythemia refers to a true increase in the total red blood cell mass. This can occur due to primary polycythemia (polycythemia vera) or secondary polycythemia due to chronic hypoxia or erythropoietin-secreting tumors.

 

Option C. Severe internal bleeding: Severe internal bleeding would typically lead to a decrease in RBC mass and hematocrit, not an increase.

 

Option D. Myeloproliferative disorder: Myeloproliferative disorders are a group of conditions that involve the overproduction of blood cells in the bone marrow, such as polycythemia vera. These disorders lead to absolute, not relative, polycythemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gaisböck syndrome is a form of relative polycythemia caused by a reduction in plasma volume, often due to dehydration, leading to an apparent increase in red blood cell concentration.

questions.text: Identify the crystal in a patient with urinary pH of 8.7: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Triple Phosphate

 

Normally, urinary pH typically ranges from 4.4 to 6.5, which is acidic.

 

Here, an alkaline urinary pH of 8.7 promotes the formation of certain types of crystals, particularly triple phosphate (struvite) and calcium phosphate crystals. The image provided shows typical "coffin-lid" shaped crystals, which are characteristic of triple phosphate (magnesium ammonium phosphate) or struvite crystals.

 

Triple Phosphate crystals are commonly associated with urinary tract infections caused by urease-positive bacteria such as Proteus, Klebsiella, and Ureaplasma urealyticum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcium Oxalate : These crystals typically form in acidic urine and have different shapes, such as envelope or dumbbell shapes.

 

Option C. Cystine : These crystals also form in acidic urine and have a distinctive hexagonal shape.

 

Option D. Uric Acid : These crystals form in acidic urine and appear as rhomboid or rosette shapes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triple phosphate (struvite) crystals are associated with alkaline urine and have a "coffin-lid" appearance. They are commonly seen in patients with urinary tract infections caused by urease-positive organisms.
